title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master Is it not pleasant to learn with a constant perseverance and application?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Is it not delightful to have friends coming from distant quarters?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Is he not a man of complete virtue, who feels no discomposure though men may take no note of him?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The philosopher Yu said, They are few who, being filial and fraternal, are fond of offending against their superiors. There have been none, who, not liking to offend against their superiors, have been fond of stirring up confusion.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The superior man bends his attention to what is radical. That being established, all practical courses naturally grow up. Filial piety and fraternal submission,-are they not the root of all benevolent actions?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Fine words and an insinuating appearance are seldom associated with true virtue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The philosopher Tsang said, I daily examine myself on three points:-whether, in transacting business for others, I may have been not faithful;-whether, in intercourse with friends, I may have been not sincere;-whether I may have not mastered and practiced the instructions of my teacher.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, To rule a country of a thousand chariots, there must be reverent attention to business, and sincerity; economy in expenditure, and love for men; and the employment of the people at the proper seasons.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, A youth, when at home, should be filial, and, abroad, respectful to his elders. He should be earnest and truthful. He should overflow in love to all, and cultivate the friendship of the good. When he has time and opportunity, after the performance of these things, he should employ them in polite studies.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-hsia said, If a man withdraws his mind from the love of beauty, and applies it as sincerely to the love of the virtuous; if, in serving his parents, he can exert his utmost strength; if, in serving his prince, he can devote his life; if, in his intercourse with his friends, his words are sincere:-although men say that he has not learned, I will certainly say that he has.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If the scholar be not grave, he will not call forth any veneration, and his learning will not be solid.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Hold faithfulness and sincerity as first principles. Have no friends not equal to yourself. When you have faults, do not fear to abandon them. The philosopher Tsang said, Let there be a careful attention to perform the funeral rites to parents, and let them be followed when long gone with the ceremonies of sacrifice;-then the virtue of the people will resume its proper excellence.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-ch'in asked Tsze-kung saying, When our master comes to any country, he does not fail to learn all about its government. Does he ask his information? or is it given to him?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung said, Our master is benign, upright, courteous, temperate, and complaisant and thus he gets his information. The master's mode of asking information,-is it not different from that of other men?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, While a man's father is alive, look at the bent of his will; when his father is dead, look at his conduct. If for three years he does not alter from the way of his father, he may be called filial.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The philosopher Yu said, In practicing the rules of propriety, a natural ease is to be prized. In the ways prescribed by the ancientkings, this is the excellent quality, and in things small and great we follow them.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Yet it is not to be observed in all cases. If one, knowing how such ease should be prized, manifests it, without regulating it by the rules of propriety, this likewise is not to be done.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The philosopher Yu said, When agreements are made according to what is right, what is spoken can be made good. When respect is shown according to what is proper, one keeps far from shame and disgrace. When the parties upon whom a man leans are proper persons to be intimate with, he can make them his guides and masters.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, He who aims to be a man of complete virtue in his food does not seek to gratify his appetite, nor in his dwelling place does he seek the appliances of ease; he is earnest in what he is doing, and careful in his speech; he frequents the company of men of principle that he may be rectified:-such a person may be said indeed to love to learn.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung said, What do you pronounce concerning the poor man who yet does not flatter, and the rich man who is not proud? The Master replied, They will do; but they are not equal to him, who, though poor, is yet cheerful, and to him, who, though rich, loves the rules of propriety.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung replied, It is said in the Book of Poetry, 'As you cut and then file, as you carve and then polish.'-The meaning is the same, I apprehend, as that which you have just expressed.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, With one like Ts'ze, I can begin to talk about the odes. I told him one point, and he knew its proper sequence.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I will not be afflicted at men's not knowing me; I will be afflicted that I do not know men.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Part 2

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, He who exercises government by means of his virtue may be compared to the north polar star, which keeps its place and all the stars turn towards it.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, In the Book of Poetry are three hundred pieces, but the design of them all may be embraced in one sentence 'Having no depraved thoughts.'

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If the people be led by laws, and uniformity sought to be given them by punishments, they will try to avoid the punishment, but have no sense of shame.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: If they be led by virtue, and uniformity sought to be given them by the rules of propriety, they will have the sense of shame, and moreover will become good.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, At fifteen, I had my mind bent on learning.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: At thirty, I stood firm. At forty, I had no doubts. At fifty, I knew the decrees of Heaven. At sixty, my ear was an obedient organ for the reception of truth.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: At seventy, I could follow what my heart desired, without transgressing what was right.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Mang I asked what filial piety was. The Master said, It is not being disobedient.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Soon after, as Fan Ch'ih was driving him, the Master told him, saying, Mang-sun asked me what filial piety was, and I answered him,-'not being disobedient.'

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Fan Ch'ih said, What did you mean? The Master replied, That parents, when alive, be served according to propriety; that, when dead, they should be buried according to propriety; and that they should be sacrificed to according to propriety.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Mang Wu asked what filial piety was. The Master said, Parents are anxious lest their children should be sick.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-yu asked what filial piety was. The Master said, The filial piety nowadays means the support of one's parents. But dogs and horses likewise are able to do something in the way of support;-without reverence, what is there to distinguish the one support given from the other?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-hsia asked what filial piety was. The Master said, The difficulty is with the countenance. If, when their elders have any troublesome affairs, the young take the toil of them, and if, when the young have wine and food, they set them before their elders, is THIS to be considered filial piety?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I have talked with Hui for a whole day, and he has not made any objection to anything I said;-as if he were stupid. He has retired, and I have examined his conduct when away from me, and found him able to illustrate my teachings. Hui!-He is not stupid.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, See what a man does. Mark his motives. Examine in what things he rests. How can a man conceal his character? How can a man conceal his character?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If a man keeps cherishing his old knowledge, so as continually to be acquiring new, he may be a teacher of others.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The accomplished scholar is not a utensil.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung asked what constituted the superior man. The Master said, He acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The superior man is catholic and not partisan. The mean man is partisan and not catholic.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Learning without thought is labor lost; thought without learning is perilous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The study of strange doctrines is injurious indeed!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Yu, shall I teach you what knowledge is? When you know a thing, to hold that you know it; and when you do not know a thing, to allow that you do not know it;-this is knowledge.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-chang was learning with a view to official emolument.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Hear much and put aside the points of which you stand in doubt, while you speak cautiously at the same time of the others:-then you will afford few occasions for blame. See much and put aside the things which seem perilous, while you are cautious at the same time in carrying the others into practice: then you will have few occasions for repentance. When one gives few occasions for blame in his words, and few occasions for repentance in his conduct, he is in the way to get emolument.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Duke Ai asked, saying, What should be done in order to secure the submission of the people? Confucius replied, Advance the upright and set aside the crooked, then the people will submit. Advance the crooked and set aside the upright, then the people will not submit.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Chi K'ang asked how to cause the people to reverence their ruler, to be faithful to him, and to go on to nerve themselves to virtue. The Master said, Let him preside over them with gravity;-then they will reverence him. Let him be final and kind to all;-then they will be faithful to him. Let him advance the good and teach the incompetent;-then they will eagerly seek to be virtuous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Some one addressed Confucius, saying, Sir, why are you not engaged in the government?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, What does the Shu-ching say of filial piety?-'You are final, you discharge your brotherly duties. These qualities are displayed in government.' This then also constitutes the exercise of government. Why must there be THAT-making one be in the government?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I do not know how a man without truthfulness is to get on. How can a large carriage be made to go without the crossbar for yoking the oxen to, or a small carriage without the arrangement for yoking the horses?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-chang asked whether the affairs of ten ages after could be known.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Confucius said, The Yin dynasty followed the regulations of the Hsia: wherein it took from or added to them may be known. The Chau dynasty has followed the regulations of Yin: wherein it took from or added to them may be known. Some other may follow the Chau, but though it should be at the distance of a hundred ages, its affairs may be known.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, For a man to sacrifice to a spirit which does not belong to him is flattery.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: To see what is right and not to do it is want of courage.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Part 3

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Confucius said of the head of the Chi family, who had eight rows of pantomimes in his area, If he can bear to do this, what may he not bear to do?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The three families used the Yungode, while the vessels were being removed, at the conclusion of the sacrifice. The Master said, 'Assisting are the princes;-the son of heaven looks profound and grave';-what application can these words have in the hall of the three families?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If a man be without the virtues proper to humanity, what has he to do with the rites of propriety? If a man be without the virtues proper to humanity, what has he to do with music?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Lin Fang asked what was the first thing to be attended to in ceremonies.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, A great question indeed! In festive ceremonies, it is better to be sparing than extravagant. In the ceremonies of mourning, it is better that there be deep sorrow than in minute attention to observances.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The rude tribes of the east and north have their princes, and are not like the States of our great land which are without them.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The chief of the Chi family was about to sacrifice to the T'ai mountain. The Master said to Zan Yu, Can you not save him from this? He answered, I cannot. Confucius said, Alas! will you say that the T'ai mountain is not so discerning as Lin Fang?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The student of virtue has no contentions. If it be said he cannot avoid them, shall this be in archery? But he bows complaisantly to his competitors; thus he ascends the hall, descends, and exacts the forfeit of drinking. In his contention, he is still the Chun-tsze.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-hsia asked, saying, What is the meaning of the passage-'The pretty dimples of her artful smile! The well-defined black and white of her eye! The plain ground for the colors?'

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The business of laying on the colors follows the preparation of the plain ground.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Ceremonies then are a subsequent thing? The Master said, It is Shang who can bring out my meaning. Now I can begin to talk about the odes with him.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I could describe the ceremonies of the Hsia dynasty, but Chi cannot sufficiently attest my words. I could describe the ceremonies of the Yin dynasty, but Sung cannot sufficiently attest my words. They cannot do so because of the insufficiency of their records and wise men. If those were sufficient, I could adduce them in support of my words.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, At the great sacrifice, after the pouring out of the libation, I have no wish to look on.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Some one asked the meaning of the great sacrifice. The Master said, I do not know. He who knew its meaning would find it as easy to govern the kingdom as to look on this-pointing to his palm.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: He sacrificed to the dead, as if they were present. He sacrificed to the spirits, as if the spirits were present.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I consider my not being present at the sacrifice, as if I did not sacrifice.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Wang-sun Chia asked, saying, What is the meaning of the saying, 'It is better to pay court to the furnace then to the southwest corner?'

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Not so. He who offends against Heaven has none to whom he can pray.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Chau had the advantage of viewing the two past dynasties. How complete and elegant are its regulations! I follow Chau.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master, when he entered the grand temple, asked about everything. Some one said, Who say that the son of the man of Tsau knows the rules of propriety! He has entered the grand temple and asks about everything. The Master heard the remark, and said, This is a rule of propriety.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, In archery it is not going through the leather which is the principal thing;-because people's strength is not equal. This was the old way.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung wished to do away with the offering of a sheep connected with the inauguration of the first day of each month.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Ts'ze, you love the sheep; I love the ceremony.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The full observance of the rules of propriety in serving one's prince is accounted by people to be flattery.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Duke Ting asked how a prince should employ his ministers, and how ministers should serve their prince. Confucius replied, A prince should employ his minister according to according to the rules of propriety; ministers should serve their prince with faithfulness.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The Kwan Tsu is expressive of enjoyment without being licentious, and of grief without being hurtfully excessive.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Duke Ai asked Tsai Wo about the altars of the spirits of the land. Tsai Wo replied, The Hsia sovereign planted the pine tree about them; the men of the Yin planted the cypress; and the men of the Chau planted the chestnut tree, meaning thereby to cause the people to be in awe.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: When the Master heard it, he said, Things that are done, it is needless to speak about; things that have had their course, it is needless to remonstrate about; things that are past, it is needless to blame.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Small indeed was the capacity of Kwan Chung!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Some one said, Was Kwan Chung parsimonious? Kwan, was the reply, had the San Kwei, and his officers performed no double duties; how can he be considered parsimonious?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Then, did Kwan Chung know the rules of propriety? The Master said, The princes of States have a screen intercepting the view at their gates. Kwan had likewise a screen at his gate. The princes of States on any friendly meeting between two of them, had a stand on which to place their inverted cups. Kwan had also such a stand. If Kwan knew the rules of propriety, who does not know them?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master instructing the grand music master of Lu said, How to play music may be known. At the commencement of the piece, all the parts should sound together. As it proceeds, they should be in harmony while severally distinct and flowing without break, and thus on to the conclusion.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The border warden at Yi requested to be introduced to the Master, saying, When men of superior virtue have come to this, I have never been denied the privilege of seeing them. The followers of the sage introduced him, and when he came out from the interview, he said, My friends, why are you distressed by your master's loss of office? The kingdom has long been without the principles of truth and right; Heaven is going to use your master as a bell with its wooden tongue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said of the Shao that it was perfectly beautiful and also perfectly good. He said of the Wu that it was perfectly beautiful but not perfectly good.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, High station filled without indulgent generosity; ceremonies performed without reverence; mourning conducted without sorrow;-wherewith should I contemplate such ways?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Part 4

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, It is virtuous manners which constitute the excellence of a neighborhood. If a man in selecting a residence do not fix on one where such prevail, how can he be wise?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Those who are without virtue cannot abide long either in a condition of poverty and hardship, or in a condition of enjoyment. The virtuous rest in virtue; the wise desire virtue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, It is only the truly virtuous man, who can love, or who can hate, others.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If the will be set on virtue, there will be no practice of wickedness.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Riches and honors are what men desire. If they cannot be obtained in the proper way, they should not be held. Poverty and meanness are what men dislike. If they cannot be avoided in the proper way, they should not be avoided.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: If a superior man abandon virtue, how can he fulfill the requirements of that name?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The superior man does not, even for the space of a single meal, act contrary to virtue. In moments of haste, he cleaves to it. In seasons of danger, he cleaves to it.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I have not seen a person who loved virtue, or one who hated what was not virtuous. He who loved virtue, would esteem nothing above it. He who hated what is not virtuous, would practice virtue in such a way that he would not allow anything that is not virtuous to approach his person.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Is any one able for one day to apply his strength to virtue? I have not seen the case in which his strength would be insufficient.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Should there possibly be any such case, I have not seen it.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The faults of men are characteristic of the class to which they belong. By observing a man's faults, it may be known that he is virtuous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If a man in the morning hear the right way, he may die in the evening hear regret.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, A scholar, whose mind is set on truth, and who is ashamed of bad clothes and bad food, is not fit to be discoursed with.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The superior man, in the world, does not set his mind either for anything, or against anything; what is right he will follow.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The superior man thinks of virtue; the small man thinks of comfort. The superior man thinks of the sanctions of law; the small man thinks of favors which he may receive.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said: He who acts with a constant view to his own advantage will be much murmured against.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If a prince is able to govern his kingdom with the complaisance proper to the rules of propriety, what difficulty will he have? If he cannot govern it with that complaisance, what has he to do with the rules of propriety?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, A man should say, I am not concerned that I have no place, I am concerned how I may fit myself for one. I am not concerned that I am not known, I seek to be worthy to be known.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Shan, my doctrine is that of an all-pervading unity. The disciple Tsang replied, Yes.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master went out, and the other disciples asked, saying, What do his words mean? Tsang said, The doctrine of our master is to be true to the principles-of our nature and the benevolent exercise of them to others,-this and nothing more.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The mind of the superior man is conversant with righteousness; the mind of the mean man is conversant with gain.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, When we see men of worth, we should think of equaling them; when we see men of a contrary character, we should turn inwards and examine ourselves.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, In serving his parents, a son may remonstrate with them, but gently; when he sees that they do not incline to follow his advice, he shows an increased degree of reverence, but does not abandon his purpose; and should they punish him, he does not allow himself to murmur.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, While his parents are alive, the son may not go abroad to a distance. If he does go abroad, he must have a fixed place to which he goes.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, If the son for three years does not alter from the way of his father, he may be called filial.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The years of parents may by no means not be kept in the memory, as an occasion at once for joy and for fear.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The reason why the ancients did not readily give utterance to their words, was that they feared lest their actions should not come up to them.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The cautious seldom err. The Master said, The superior man wishes to be slow in his speech and earnest in his conduct.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Virtue is not left to stand alone. He who practices it will have neighbors.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-yu said, In serving a prince, frequent remonstrances lead to disgrace. Between friends, frequent reproofs make the friendship distant.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Part 5

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said of Kung-ye Ch'ang that he might be wived; although he was put in bonds, he had not been guilty of any crime. Accordingly, he gave him his own daughter to wife.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Of Nan Yung he said that if the country were well governed he would not be out of office, and if it were in governed, he would escape punishment and disgrace. He gave him the daughter of his own elder brother to wife.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said of Tsze-chien, Of superior virtue indeed is such a man! If there were not virtuous men in Lu, how could this man have acquired this character?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung asked, What do you say of me, Ts'ze! The Master said, You are a utensil. What utensil? A gemmed sacrificial utensil.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Some one said, Yung is truly virtuous, but he is not ready with his tongue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, What is the good of being ready with the tongue? They who encounter men with smartness of speech for the most part procure themselves hatred. I know not whether he be truly virtuous, but why should he show readiness of the tongue?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master was wishing Ch'i-tiao K'ai to enter an official employment. He replied, I am not yet able to rest in the assurance of this. The Master was pleased.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, My doctrines make no way. I will get upon a raft, and float about on the sea. He that will accompany me will be Yu, I dare say. Tsze-lu hearing this was glad, upon which the Master said, Yu is fonder of daring than I am. He does not exercise his judgment upon matters.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Mang Wu asked about Tsze-lu, whether he was perfectly virtuous. The Master said, I do not know.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: He asked again, when the Master replied, In a kingdom of a thousand chariots, Yu might be employed to manage the military levies, but I do not know whether he be perfectly virtuous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: And what do you say of Ch'iu? The Master replied, In a city of a thousand families, or a clan of a hundred chariots, Ch'iu might be employed as governor, but I do not know whether he is perfectly virtuous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: What do you say of Ch'ih? The Master replied, With his sash girt and standing in a court, Ch'ih might be employed to converse with the visitors and guests, but I do not know whether he is perfectly virtuous.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said to Tsze-kung, Which do you consider superior, yourself or Hui?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung replied, How dare I compare myself with Hui? Hui hears one point and knows all about a subject; I hear one point, and know a second.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, You are not equal to him. I grant you, you are not equal to him.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsai Yu being asleep during the daytime, the Master said, Rotten wood cannot be carved; a wall of dirty earth will not receive the trowel. This Yu,-what is the use of my reproving him?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, At first, my way with men was to hear their words, and give them credit for their conduct. Now my way is to hear their words, and look at their conduct. It is from Yu that I have learned to make this change.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, I have not seen a firm and unbending man. Some one replied, There is Shan Ch'ang. Ch'ang, said the Master, is under the influence of his passions; how can he be pronounced firm and unbending?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung said, What I do not wish men to do to me, I also wish not to do to men. The Master said, Ts'ze, you have not attained to that.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung said, The Master's personal displays of his principles and ordinary descriptions of them may be heard. His discourses about man's nature, and the way of Heaven, cannot be heard.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: When Tsze-lu heard anything, if he had not yet succeeded in carrying it into practice, he was only afraid lest he should hear something else.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung asked, saying, On what ground did Kung-wan get that title of Wan?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, He was of an active nature and yet fond of learning, and he was not ashamed to ask and learn of his inferiors!-On these grounds he has been styled Wan.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said of Tsze-ch'an that he had four of the characteristics of a superior man-in his conduct of himself, he was humble; in serving his superior, he was respectful; in nourishing the people, he was kind; in ordering the people, he was just.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Yen P'ing knew well how to maintain friendly intercourse. The acquaintance might be long, but he showed the same respect as at first.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Tsang Wan kept a large tortoise in a house, on the capitals of the pillars of which he had hills made, and with representations of duckweed on the small pillars above the beams supporting the rafters.-Of what sort was his wisdom?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-chang asked, saying, The minister Tsze-wan thrice took office, and manifested no joy in his countenance. Thrice he retired from office, and manifested no displeasure. He made it a point to inform the new minister of the way in which he had conducted the government; what do you say of him? The Master replied. He was loyal. Was he perfectly virtuous? I do not know. How can he be pronounced perfectly virtuous?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-chang proceeded, When the officer Ch'ui killed the prince of Ch'i, Ch'an Wan, though he was the owner of forty horses, abandoned them and left the country. Coming to another state, he said, 'They are here like our great officer, Ch'ui,' and left it. He came to a second state, and with the same observation left it also;-what do you say of him? The Master replied, He was pure. Was he perfectly virtuous? I do not know. How can he be pronounced perfectly virtuous?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Chi Wan thought thrice, and then acted. When the Master was informed of it, he said, Twice may do.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, When good order prevailed in his country, Ning Wu acted the part of a wise man. When his country was in disorder, he acted the part of a stupid man. Others may equal his wisdom, but they cannot equal his stupidity.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: When the Master was in Ch'an, he said, Let me return! Let me return! The little children of my school are ambitious and too hasty. They are accomplished and complete so far, but they do not know how to restrict and shape themselves.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Po-i and Shu-ch'i did not keep the former wickednesses of men in mind, and hence the resentments directed towards them were few.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Who says of Weishang Kao that he is upright? One begged some vinegar of him, and he begged it of a neighbor and gave it to the man.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Fine words, an insinuating appearance, and excessive respect;-Tso Ch'iu-ming was ashamed of them. I also am ashamed of them. To conceal resentment against a person, and appear friendly with him;-Tso Ch'iu-ming was ashamed of such conduct. I also am ashamed of it.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Yen Yuan and Chi Lu being by his side, the Master said to them, Come, let each of you tell his wishes.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-lu said, I should like, having chariots and horses, and light fur clothes, to share them with my friends, and though they should spoil them, I would not be displeased.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Yen Yuan said, I should like not to boast of my excellence, nor to make a display of my meritorious deeds.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-lu then said, I should like, sir, to hear your wishes. The Master said, They are, in regard to the aged, to give them rest; in regard to friends, to show them sincerity; in regard to the young, to treat them tenderly.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, It is all over. I have not yet seen one who could perceive his faults, and inwardly accuse himself.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, In a hamlet of ten families, there may be found one honorable and sincere as I am, but not so fond of learning.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Part 6

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, There is Yung!-He might occupy the place of a prince.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Chung-kung asked about Tsze-sang Po-tsze. The Master said, He may pass. He does not mind small matters.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Chung-kung said, If a man cherish in himself a reverential feeling of the necessity of attention to business, though he may be easy in small matters in his government of the people, that may be allowed. But if he cherish in himself that easy feeling, and also carry it out in his practice, is not such an easymode of procedure excessive?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Yung's words are right. The Duke Ai asked which of the disciples loved to learn.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Confucius replied to him, There was Yen Hui; he loved to learn. He did not transfer his anger; he did not repeat a fault. Unfortunately, his appointed time was short and he died; and now there is not such another. I have not yet heard of any one who loves to learn as he did.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-hwa being employed on a mission to Ch'i, the disciple Zan requested grain for his mother. The Master said, Give her a fu. Yen requested more. Give her a yi, said the Master. Yen gave her five ping.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, When Ch'ih was proceeding to Ch'i, he had fat horses to his carriage, and wore light furs. I have heard that a superior man helps the distressed, but does not add to the wealth of the rich.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Yuan Sze being made governor of his town by the Master, he gave him nine hundred measures of grain, but Sze declined them.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Do not decline them. May you not give them away in the neighborhoods, hamlets, towns, and villages?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master, speaking of Chung-kung, said, If the calf of a brindled cow be red and homed, although men may not wish to use it, would the spirits of the mountains and rivers put it aside?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Such was Hui that for three months there would be nothing in his mind contrary to perfect virtue. The others may attain to this on some days or in some months, but nothing more.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Chi K'ang asked about Chung-yu, whether he was fit to be employed as an officer of government. The Master said, Yu is a man of decision; what difficulty would he find in being an officer of government? K'ang asked, Is Ts'ze fit to be employed as an officer of government? and was answered, Ts'ze is a man of intelligence; what difficulty would he find in being an officer of government? And to the same question about Ch'iu the Master gave the same reply, saying, Ch'iu is a man of various ability.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The chief of the Chi family sent to ask Min Tsze-ch'ien to be governor of Pi. Min Tszech'ien said, Decline the offer for me politely. If any one come again to me with a second invitation, I shall be obliged to go and live on the banks of the Wan.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Po-niu being ill, the Master went to ask for him. He took hold of his hand through the window, and said, It is killing him. It is the appointment of Heaven, alas! That such a man should have such a sickness! That such a man should have such a sickness!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Admirable indeed was the virtue of Hui! With a single bamboo dish of rice, a single gourd dish of drink, and living in his mean narrow lane, while others could not have endured the distress, he did not allow his joy to be affected by it. Admirable indeed was the virtue of Hui!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Yen Ch'iu said, It is not that I do not delight in your doctrines, but my strength is insufficient. The Master said, Those whose strength is insufficient give over in the middle of the way but now you limit yourself.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said to Tsze-hsia, Do you be a scholar after the style of the superior man, and not after that of the mean man.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-yu being governor of Wu-ch'ang, the Master said to him, Have you got good men there? He answered, There is Tan-t'ai Miehming, who never in walking takes a short cut, and never comes to my office, excepting on public business.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Mang Chih-fan does not boast of his merit. Being in the rear on an occasion of flight, when they were about to enter the gate, he whipped up his horse, saying, It is not that I dare to be last. My horse would not advance.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Without the specious speech of the litanist T'o and the beauty of the prince Chao of Sung, it is difficult to escape in the present age.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Who can go out but by the door? How is it that men will not walk according to these ways?

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Where the solid qualities are in excess of accomplishments, we have rusticity; where the accomplishments are in excess of the solid qualities, we have the manners of a clerk. When the accomplishments and solid qualities are equally blended, we then have the man of virtue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Man is born for uprightness. If a man lose his uprightness, and yet live, his escape from death is the effect of mere good fortune.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, They who know the truth are not equal to those who love it, and they who love it are not equal to those who delight in it.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, To those whose talents are above mediocrity, the highest subjects may be announced. To those who are below mediocrity, the highest subjects may not be announced.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Fan Ch'ih asked what constituted wisdom. The Master said, To give one's self earnestly to the duties due to men, and, while respecting spiritual beings, to keep aloof from them, may be called wisdom. He asked about perfect virtue. The Master said, The man of virtue makes the difficulty to be overcome his first business, and success only a subsequent consideration;-this may be called perfect virtue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The wise find pleasure in water; the virtuous find pleasure in hills. The wise are active; the virtuous are tranquil. The wise are joyful; the virtuous are long-lived.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Ch'i, by one change, would come to the State of Lu. Lu, by one change, would come to a State where true principles predominated.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, A cornered vessel without corners-a strange cornered vessel! A strange cornered vessel!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsai Wo asked, saying, A benevolent man, though it be told him,-'There is a man in the well will go in after him, I suppose. Confucius said, Why should he do so? A superior man may be made to go to the well, but he cannot be made to go down into it. He may be imposed upon, but he cannot be fooled.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, The superior man, extensively studying all learning, and keeping himself under the restraint of the rules of propriety, may thus likewise not overstep what is right.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master having visited Nan-tsze, Tsze-lu was displeased, on which the Master swore, saying, Wherein I have done improperly, may Heaven reject me, may Heaven reject me!

title: Analects by Confucius
text: The Master said, Perfect is the virtue which is according to the Constant Mean! Rare for a long time has been its practice among the people.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Tsze-kung said, Suppose the case of a man extensively conferring benefits on the people, and able to assist all, what would you say of him? Might he be called perfectly virtuous? The Master said, Why speak only of virtue in connection with him? Must he not have the qualities of a sage? Even Yao and Shun were still solicitous about this.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Now the man of perfect virtue, wishing to be established himself, seeks also to establish others; wishing to be enlarged himself, he seeks also to enlarge others.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: To be able to judge of others by what is nigh in ourselves;-this may be called the art of virtue.

title: Analects by Confucius
text: Home
